text: You're deleting items from list1 while you're iterating over it.
That's asking for trouble.
Try this:

code:
>>> list1 = [1,2,3,4,5,6]
>>> list2 = []
>>> list2 = list1[:] # we copy every element from list1 using a slice
>>> del list1[:] # we delete every element from list1

text: The reason is that you're (appending and) removing from the first list whereby it gets smaller.
So the iterator stops before the whole list could be walked through.
To achieve what you want, do this:

code:
list1 = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
list2 = []

# You couldn't just make 'list1_copy = list1',
# because this would just copy (share) the reference.
# (i.e. when you change list1_copy, list1 will also change)

# this will make a (new) copy of list1
# so you can happily iterate over it ( without anything getting lost :)
list1_copy = list1[:]

for item in list1_copy:
    list2.append(item)
    list1.remove(item)

text: The list1[start:end:step] is the slicing syntax: when you leave start empty it defaults to 0, when you leave end empty it is the highest possible value.
So list1[:] means everything in it.
(thanks to Wallacoloo)
Like some dudes said, you could also use the extend-method of the list-object to just copy the one list to another, if this was your intention.
(But I choosed the way above, because this is near to your approach.
As you are new to python, I have something for you: Dive Into Python 3 - it's free and easy.
- Have fun!
Essential debugging skill:  Add print statements.
(or print functions in Python 3)

code:
>>> list1= [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
>>> for item in list1:
...     print item
...     list1.remove(item)
...     print list1
... 
1
[2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
3
[2, 4, 5, 6]
5
[2, 4, 6]

text: Notice that Python is trying to step through the positions of the list, but you keep removing items from the list, making the positions become meaningless.
Python picks the item at position 0 from the list.
You then remove the item, changing the list.
Python then picks the item at position 1 from the list (appearing to skip an item)
You then remove that item, changing the list.
Python then picks the item at position 2 from the list (appearing to skip an item)
You then remove the item, changing the list.
Python would then like to pick the item at position 3, but there's no such item.
So the loop stops.
You shouldn't modify a list while you iterate over it.
This causes the iterator to point at the wrong item.
After the first item is handled, the iterator is pointing at index = 1, but because you've removed an item, the next item is now at index zero, so it will be skipped.
This is why you are only handling every other item.
Try:

code:
list2.extend(list1) # This appends all items from list1 to list2.
 del list1[:] # From ChristopheD's post.

text: There is also the humble copy function (or deepcopy if you have complex objects and not just integers in your list):

code:
from copy import copy

list2 = copy(list1)

text: You might get a more appropriate answer if you explain what you're trying to accomplish (unless you're just learning about python lists).
"Variables" in Python are just names/references, so the destructive copy you seem to want to do seems kind of strange.
If you want list2 to have the same values as list1 you can just do:

code: list2 = list1 # now they are both referring to the same list

text: And if after that you want to use list1 for something else, you can just do:
As you can see in other answers, you are trying to modify the list while iterating over it.
This doesn't work.
There are many ways to copy one list to another.
I did some tests to see how fast each approach is:

code:
>>> timeit.Timer('list2 = list1[:]', 'list1 = range(10**3)').timeit(10**6)
3.9134418964385986

>>> timeit.Timer('list2 = []; list2.extend(list1)', 'list1 = range(10**3)').timeit(10**6)
4.9082601070404053

>>> timeit.Timer('list2 = copy.copy(list1)', 'import copy; list1 = range(10**3)').timeit(10**6)
7.5023419857025146

>>> timeit.Timer('list2 = [i for i in list1]', 'list1 = range(10**3)').timeit(10**6)
95.697894811630249

text: The slice syntax is the fastest.
It's much faster than using a list comprehension.

Exactly as ChristopheD says.
Could do this:

code:
list1 = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
list2 = []

for item in list1:
    list2.append(item)

list1 = []

text: That'll clear list1.

@potatocubed: Many of the answers given solve the trivial example you gave ("move list1 to list2"), but don't really explain the "why" of the deeper problem, which is modifying a list as you iterate over it.
